[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][/et_pb_row][/et_pb_section][et_pb_section fb_built=”1″ _builder_version=”3.22″ custom_padding=”0|0px|74px|0|false|false”][et_pb_row column_structure=”2_3,1_3″ _builder_version=”4.9.7″ background_size=”initial” background_position=”top_left” background_repeat=”repeat” custom_margin=”||50px||false|false” custom_margin_tablet=”|||” custom_margin_phone=”” custom_margin_last_edited=”on|phone” custom_padding=”61px|0px|0|0|false|false” custom_css_before=”width: 190px;||height: 482px;||content: ”;||background-image: url(/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/Talking-with-youth-doodle.png);||position: absolute;||left: -220px;||top: 0px;||background-size: cover;||transform: rotate(-15deg);”][et_pb_column type=”2_3″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text admin_label=”Intro Title” _builder_version=”4.9.6″ text_font=”||||||||” text_text_color=”#4b858e” header_font=”|||on|||||” header_text_color=”#4b858e” header_2_font=”|300|||||||” header_3_font=”Zooja Pro|100|||||||” header_3_text_align=”left” header_3_text_color=”#cccdce” header_3_font_size=”82px” header_3_letter_spacing=”-0.1px” header_3_line_height=”0.8em” custom_margin=”||0px||false|false” header_3_font_size_tablet=”50px” header_3_font_size_phone=”40px” header_3_font_size_last_edited=”on|desktop”]

[/et_pb_text][et_pb_text admin_label=”Intro Quote” _builder_version=”4.9.6″ text_font=”|300|||||||” text_text_color=”#636466″ text_font_size=”24px” text_line_height=”30px”]

He mea uaua ki te korero, engari he mea whakahirahira (its hard to talk about – but important)

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][et_pb_column type=”1_3″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text module_class=”col-quote-block” _builder_version=”4.9.6″ _module_preset=”default”]“I know friends who have been in these difficult (porn) situations but don’t want to ask for help because of the judgement they don’t want to receive.”
—Anon young person, TLP ITK survey [/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][/et_pb_row][et_pb_row _builder_version=”4.9.7″ background_color=”rgba(191,154,70,0.21)” custom_margin=”||80px||false|false” custom_padding=”25px|25px|25px|25px|true|true” border_color_all=”#FFFFFF” box_shadow_style=”preset3″ box_shadow_color=”rgba(131,0,233,0.12)”][et_pb_column type=”4_4″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text _builder_version=”4.9.7″ _module_preset=”default” text_font=”|300|||||||” text_text_color=”#BF9A46″ text_orientation=”center”]

Here’s some simple tips for talking to your teen about porn including:
preparing for the conversation, conversation openers, topics to talk about,
helpful resources and keeping the lines open.

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][/et_pb_row][et_pb_row custom_padding_last_edited=”on|phone” _builder_version=”4.9.7″ custom_padding=”0px|0px|0|0px|false|false” custom_padding_tablet=”0px||||false|false” custom_padding_phone=””][et_pb_column type=”4_4″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text admin_label=”Intro Text” _builder_version=”3.27.4″ header_font=”||||||||” header_font_size=”88px” header_4_text_color=”#4b858e” header_4_font_size=”24px”]

Before you talk …

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][/et_pb_row][et_pb_row column_structure=”1_3,1_3,1_3″ _builder_version=”3.25″ background_size=”initial” background_position=”top_left” background_repeat=”repeat” max_width=”1440px” custom_padding=”27px|0px|0|0px|false|false” use_custom_width=”on” custom_width_px=”1440px”][et_pb_column type=”1_3″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text admin_label=”Intro Text” _builder_version=”3.27.4″ header_font=”||||||||” header_4_font=”||||||||” header_4_text_color=”#4b858e” header_4_font_size=”24px”]

GET PREPARED

If you haven’t spoken with young people about porn before, check out the Porn 101 fact sheet to get the lowdown on porn, or you might even like to check out the porn talk preparation tips for whānau: BLAT (Breathe, Learn, Ally, Talk)

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][et_pb_column type=”1_3″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text admin_label=”Intro Text” _builder_version=”4.9.10″ header_font=”||||||||” header_4_font=”||||||||” header_4_text_color=”#4b858e” header_4_font_size=”24px” hover_enabled=”0″ sticky_enabled=”0″]

Prepare to be
un-shockable

The chances are pretty high that the teen you are talking to has seen porn. Try not to act surprised about what they tell you, particularly if they talk about the type of porn they’ve seen. This isn’t the time for shame and blame, so avoid words like bad or wrong and take a curious, open, non-judgemental approach.

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][et_pb_column type=”1_3″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text admin_label=”Intro Text” _builder_version=”4.9.10″ header_font=”||||||||” header_4_font=”||||||||” header_4_text_color=”#4b858e” header_4_font_size=”24px” hover_enabled=”0″ sticky_enabled=”0″]

Good rapport

Porn is a tough topic to bring up so make sure you have a good rapport with the young person you’re speaking with and that they feel safe with you.

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][/et_pb_row][et_pb_row column_structure=”1_3,1_3,1_3″ _builder_version=”3.25″ background_size=”initial” background_position=”top_left” background_repeat=”repeat” max_width=”1440px” custom_padding=”27px|0px|0|0px|false|false” use_custom_width=”on” custom_width_px=”1440px”][et_pb_column type=”1_3″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text admin_label=”Intro Text” _builder_version=”4.9.10″ header_font=”||||||||” header_4_font=”||||||||” header_4_text_color=”#4b858e” header_4_font_size=”24px” hover_enabled=”0″ sticky_enabled=”0″]

Choose the right time, place and environment

Talking while doing an activity can work well as it can be less intense or confrontational. Some teens prefer to chat one to one, while others may like to talk in a group. Talking about porn with friends can be quite acceptable amongst some teens and doesn’t have the same stigma it does for most adults.

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][et_pb_column type=”1_3″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text admin_label=”Intro Text” _builder_version=”4.9.6″ header_font=”||||||||” header_4_font=”||||||||” header_4_text_color=”#4b858e” header_4_font_size=”24px” custom_margin=”||5px|”]

THINGS TO CONSIDER

Some young people may have had negative experiences with porn and want to talk about this, but they’re too embarrassed to raise it on their own. It’s great to be aware of some of the common porn related issues that teens can face as you go into the conversation.

[/et_pb_text][et_pb_toggle title=”These can Include … ” open_toggle_text_color=”#4b858e” open_toggle_background_color=”#f8f8f8″ closed_toggle_text_color=”#4b858e” closed_toggle_background_color=”rgba(0,0,0,0)” icon_color=”rgba(0,0,0,0)” _builder_version=”4.9.6″ title_level=”h1″ title_font=”||||||||” title_text_align=”center” title_font_size=”34px” body_font=”||||||||” custom_padding=”20px|20px|20px|20px|true|true” animation_style=”bounce” border_width_all=”0px”]

  • Feeling their porn use is out of control.
  • Seeking increasingly violent porn themes – and feeling uncomfortable with it, but unable to stop.
  • Feeling pressure to do something sexually that a partner has seen in porn, but not wanting to.
  • Having sent images of themselves around and regretting it, but feeling too afraid to tell an adult.
  • Experiencing pressure to send nude photos.
  • Revenge porn (someone distributing nudes without consent); note: teens in the LGBTQI+ community are at increased risk of having experienced revenge porn/image-based abuse.
  • Feeling pressure to watch porn by friends or a partner.
  • Feeling upset, anxious or traumatised by images in porn, especially when there’s a history of sexual abuse.

If you are interested in learning more about some of the issues young people are wanting help with around porn, check out our latest youth site IN THE KNOW with tips, tools and info on the tricky porn related stuff.

[/et_pb_toggle][/et_pb_column][et_pb_column type=”1_3″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text admin_label=”Intro Text” _builder_version=”4.9.10″ header_font=”||||||||” header_4_font=”||||||||” header_4_text_color=”#4b858e” header_4_font_size=”24px” hover_enabled=”0″ sticky_enabled=”0″]

A note on shame

Surveys with young kiwis have shown that a lot of young people feel uncomfortable about their experiences with porn. They might know some of the porn they watch is violent, but also feel aroused by seeing nude bodies. This can result in them feeling shameful about their porn use and make it extra hard to talk to adults about it. Normalising young people’s experiences with porn can really help this “Its okay to feel lots of things when you watch porn.. curious, grossed out and aroused – that’s normal.”

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][/et_pb_row][/et_pb_section][et_pb_section fb_built=”1″ _builder_version=”4.9.6″ background_color=”rgba(191,154,70,0.21)”][et_pb_row _builder_version=”3.25″ background_size=”initial” background_position=”top_left” background_repeat=”repeat” custom_padding=”27px|0px|16px|0px|false|false”][et_pb_column type=”4_4″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text admin_label=”Intro Text” _builder_version=”3.27.4″ header_font=”||||||||” header_font_size=”88px” header_4_text_color=”#4b858e” header_4_font_size=”24px”]

Some Conversation openers …

[/et_pb_text][et_pb_text admin_label=”Intro Text” _builder_version=”4.9.7″ header_4_text_color=”#BF9A46″ header_4_font_size=”24px”]We recommend starting with a curious, open, questioning approach. Before you dive straight into asking about a teen’s porn experiences, you could start with asking questions about their friends or peers attitudes towards porn and how they feel about it?

Ask open questions (ones that start with what, how and why) that get their perspective on porn and listen&nbspwith&nbspempathy.

Here’s some opening lines to get underway …

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][/et_pb_row][et_pb_row column_structure=”1_3,1_3,1_3″ _builder_version=”3.25″ background_size=”initial” background_position=”top_left” background_repeat=”repeat”][et_pb_column type=”1_3″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text _builder_version=”4.9.6″ transform_rotate=”0deg|0deg|-3deg”]

“I heard that most young people are learning about sex through porn now, what do you think?”

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][et_pb_column type=”1_3″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text _builder_version=”4.9.6″ transform_rotate=”0deg|0deg|2deg”]

“Are your friends talking about or watching porn? What do you think about porn?”

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][et_pb_column type=”1_3″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text _builder_version=”4.9.6″ transform_rotate=”0deg|0deg|-2deg”]

“I heard about research suggesting that watching porn can affect your sex life. What do you think?”

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][/et_pb_row][/et_pb_section][et_pb_section fb_built=”1″ _builder_version=”4.9.6″ background_color=”rgba(191,154,70,0.5)”][et_pb_row _builder_version=”4.9.6″ background_size=”initial” background_position=”top_left” background_repeat=”repeat” custom_padding=”||19px||false|false”][et_pb_column type=”4_4″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text admin_label=”Intro Text” _builder_version=”4.9.6″ header_font=”||||||||” header_text_color=”#333333″ header_font_size=”88px” header_4_text_color=”#4b858e” header_4_font_size=”24px”]

Conversation Ideas …

[/et_pb_text][et_pb_text admin_label=”Intro Text” _builder_version=”4.9.6″ text_text_color=”#333333″ header_4_text_color=”#4b858e” header_4_font_size=”24px” custom_margin=”||52px|||”]

Once you’ve got the conversation started, you can start helping a teen to develop their porn literacy. This means helping them learn to analyse and identify some of the messaging in porn (like whether its sexist or racist) and to critically examine how porn messaging relates to real life sex in terms of consent, respect, safety, health and pleasure.

[/et_pb_text][et_pb_text admin_label=”Intro Text” _builder_version=”4.9.6″ header_4_text_color=”#BF9A46″ header_4_font_size=”24px” header_4_line_height=”1.1em”]

Here are a few questions you could ask …

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][/et_pb_row][et_pb_row column_structure=”1_3,1_3,1_3″ _builder_version=”3.25″ background_size=”initial” background_position=”top_left” background_repeat=”repeat”][et_pb_column type=”1_3″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text _builder_version=”4.9.10″ transform_rotate=”0deg|0deg|-2deg” hover_enabled=”0″ sticky_enabled=”0″]

What’s the difference between porn sex and good real-life sex?

Good sex always includes consent, respect, connection and pleasure for both partners. Porn sex by comparison contains a lot of sexual aggression, there’s very little focus on mutual pleasure, males frequently dominate females (or one partner ‘dominates’ another in some gay porn) and there’s often a lack of consent. Porn might show young people sex, body parts and what goes where – but it doesn’t teach them how to have respectful, meaningful and healthy sex in the real world.

“What kind of sex is porn teaching us?”

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][et_pb_column type=”1_3″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text _builder_version=”4.9.10″ transform_rotate=”0deg|0deg|1deg” hover_enabled=”0″ sticky_enabled=”0″]

Porn and body image – are porn bodies real?

Most porn uses professional actors, many of whom have surgically altered bodies or use performance enhancing stimulants such as Viagra. This can be hard for young people watching porn as it can cause unrealistic sexual expectations. Teens can start to feel pressure to ‘perform’ sexually or look like porn stars, which can cause body image and self-esteem issues.

 “Is porn realistic?”

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][et_pb_column type=”1_3″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text _builder_version=”4.9.10″ transform_rotate=”0deg|0deg|2deg” hover_enabled=”0″ sticky_enabled=”0″]

 What’s the impact of porn in the bedroom? 

From our experience, this one seems to get young people’s attention! Frequent porn use can really start to impact young people’s sex lives – for the worse. Males who watch porn regularly are more likely to be coercive (pressuring a partner to do something they don’t want to) and sexually aggressive with their partners. They can find it hard to get turned on without porn, are more likely to have problems maintaining erections, and can end up preferring porn to real partners. Porn can also make young people develop unrealistic sexual expectations, so real-life sex isn’t as pleasurable.

“Look after your sex drive, you’ll need it in the future.”

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][/et_pb_row][/et_pb_section][et_pb_section fb_built=”1″ _builder_version=”4.9.6″ background_color=”RGBA(0,0,0,0)”][et_pb_row _builder_version=”3.25″ background_size=”initial” background_position=”top_left” background_repeat=”repeat”][et_pb_column type=”4_4″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text admin_label=”Intro Text” _builder_version=”4.9.6″ header_4_text_color=”#4b858e” header_4_font_size=”24px”]
